name: NWN Character Class Guides: An attempt at a comprehensive list of what is available
author: Orion

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
NWN Character Class Guides: An attempt at a comprehensive list of what is available
I've tried to create a 'one stop' resource to easily find a comprehensive list of guides on character classes. It also helps identify areas where there might be gaps in knowledge. It's good reading too, especially for players like myself who have limited knowledge of some other classes. I thought I might as well post it up on the ECB forum as well. I've included all the guides I could find which appear to have been created with a degree of seriousness and effort, along with relevant forum discussions etc... regardless of whether I agree or not with the content (The ECB guides, with the degree of expert peer review involved, are generally excellent)

I have used Google Search to find relevant links, and searched the ECB Archives, the ECB Tapatalk Forum, the World of Greyhawk Tapatalk Forum and some of the legacy Bioware forums (smf.asmodei.net/index.php - unfortunately I don't have MS SQL) for material.

ECB and World of Greyhawk (WoG) content I have listed first. Other content listed after. 

Almost certainly there will be guides and authors that I've missed. If there are any I'm happy to go searching for the guide/post if you can't remember where it is or came from.

Maybe if the list is good enough, I'm happy for the forum moderators to pin it. I also give full permission (and encourage) for the forum moderators to modify my list as they see fit. 

General guides
Maximillian Kane's A complete guide for building a character (https://world-of-greyhawk.github.io/bui ... 16836.html, a-complete-guide-to-the-basics-of-chara ... 15440.html)
Mithdradates's Building a character: Advice. (https://world-of-greyhawk.github.io/bui ... 47382.html)
Various forum replies to a query about the 'best' caster, AB, AC, damage, HP and range builds, 2010. (https://world-of-greyhawk.github.io/bui ... 16084.html)
Concept--Yardstick Builds by the ECB Forum (concept-yardstick-builds-t2293896.html) - a collection of pure class builds 
Mithdradates Arcane Spells for the high level caster. (http://world-of-greyhawk.github.io/buil ... 80808.html)

Countess Terra's How BAB Works (https://web.archive.org/web/20081222030 ... pic=407381)

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
Mick Dagger wrote: I see that you have given me credit for a Ranger guide that rightfully belongs to Mithdradates. I hope you will edit that.
Thanks Mick for letting me know, it was unclear to me in the archive post whether it was yourself or Mith, somehow both names got listed. this is fixed!
Sometimes I look at those archives posts and wonder to myself as if that was a golden age, and also wonder, perhaps there is a golden age ahead of us...
I'd encourage others to comment / tell me if things are missing. I've just pulled up as much data as I could with the search skills I have (which admittedly are good) but I've only been seriously looking at the forums for a period of months whereas others have been active for years.
Even if one thinks it has vanished in the abyss, there is the Wayback Archive which could have taken an image of a website before it goes down.

Stagmeister:
Just for interest - how much coffee are you on atm Orion? 
I only have two mugs / day. Lavazza brand Qualita Oro from my plunger / day. It is divine. My rule is no coffee beyond 2pm! I promise you I have received no endorsements (although if Lavazza is reading this, they are welcome to assist with additional supply! )

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
I had a look at some of the guides, the AC & Fighter guides in particular.

Terrible advice from the ECB standards perspective & clearly written by people who had little to no experience into anything particularly challenging.

I quote from the AC guide in Wiki " having an AC that is insufficient, even if only by five or ten points, is not significantly better or worse in combat than having a poor AC. "
And " Thus, one's armor class is only relevant if it is significantly higher than the attacker's attack bonus. "

In other words, if you have an AC that is not significantly higher than your opponent's AB, it's better to abandon AC altogether.
That might hold water in 2nd edition AD&D where all iterative attacks had the SAME attack bonus & where power attack & weapon masters did not exist, but here is a completely false claim.
About the only build that can afford to ignore AC altogether is this one* => http://world-of-greyhawk.github.io/buil ... 52820.html
* And spellcasters in general but only when played by experienced players.

If you abandon AC altogether & go play in any kind of challenging environment, your character will get destroyed in a couple of rounds.

Something similar happens with the fighter's guide, where the sample build has two different WF, both in slashing, two-handed weapons...and then goes to finish on an odd strength score (21).
At least, he takes improved disarm & improved knockdown.

I have an almost complete AC-guide from back in 014' maybe it's time for me (or anyone else, for that matter) to actually finish it.

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
Valerfor wrote:
I have an almost complete AC-guide from back in 014' maybe it's time for me (or anyone else, for that matter) to actually finish it.
That would be welcome! I certainly wouldn't be good enough to write one!

I kept some of the other guides for comparison reasons - you can see the quality of the ECB guides or guides written by ECB affiliated players is extremely high, and it isn't surprising with the depth of knowledge and experience plus the peer review process and the preparedness to comment if there is something that doesn't look right. Also some of the non ECB lower quality guides are still of some value to players starting out in NWN (with all the NWN EE specials going on), but for advanced players the value is pretty low.

I tried to put the better guides first in the list, but for some classes there isn't a lot of good stuff out there. That means there is space for a fighter guide :) if someone wishes to write one. And a wizard one. and a barbarian one.... and a shifter guide... so much fertile ground if others are interested...

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Orion2019 wrote: that means there is space for a fighter guide :) if someone wishes to write one. And a wizard one. and a barbarian one.... and a shifter guide... so much fertile ground if others are interested...
You just had to mention Shifter, didn't you? Couldn't have said Pale Master or anything like that? You've read the Druid Guide and seen how aggravated some folk can get - and Hip's still not here! Now: "your mission, should you choose to accept it, is to find an expert in the class to produce said guide. This tape will self-destruct in 5 seconds..." (possibly a misquote )

Thanks for all your effort, Orion

posts.author: Orion
posts.content: Sorry Stag I couldn't resist :) I'd love a Pale Master guide too that is a good point!

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
I had a look at the sorcerer documents.
The threads here from our forum contain a lot of useful information, but we need a more comprehensive guide.

Blah's guide is from june 2002. I remember reading it before I tried out the sorcerer class for the first time. It was written before the expansions when the roof was level 20. The expansions added epic levels, prestige classes, new feats, skills and last, but not least a lot of new spells. The guide contains some perspectives that still hold true, but naturally it is does not cover how you can play and build today after the expansions. The fact that the guide is 17 years old means that the way people play the class also has evolved.

Cook's document does not cover how to play a sorcerer the first 12 levels as the title suggests. It does not contain much information and in my opinion it does not qualify as a guide.

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
I would definitely read a sorcerer guide written by the ECB! I would also refer anyone asking me about the class to it!

I've edited the post to change Cook's document to 'Playing a Sorcerer'. I read through the first paragraph and glanced through the rest and assumed he only played his character to 12 based on what he wrote (which clearly he had done more than that)

The quality is poor compared to a guide written with ECB standards plus peer-review. He puts some tactics which sound of dubious quality (at least by 2019 standards) in and a list of recommended spells up to level 9 spells without really explaining a lot of detail why he chose those spells. Having little experience playing sorcerer I cannot verify how good such tactics would be. I left it there at the bottom of the list. 

I was generous as to what defined a guide. If there was evidence of effort and any useful discussion/learning aimed at improving gameplay I included it, no matter the skill level of the guide creator.  The only 'guides' I did not include were the 'alteredgamer.com' class so called guides. I do not believe them to be guides as they basically cut and paste the class descriptions and requirements and have a whole bunch of advertisements to raise advertising revenue. If you google 'harper scout guide nwn 1' for example, you will get these websites come up in the results. They are awful.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Alright, I'm going to try to be an adult for a while. Thus far, it seems to me that what we're looking at here in this thread is, in effect, a Guide equivalent of the Build Request/ Unfinalized Builds section - and that's no bad thing. We're looking to be the premium builder site for NwN, are we not? While, yes, we can play nice and light with many things, that building is the core of the Guild, and we want to attract others to us for them to see the value of quality builds and join us - and there are, after all, many variations (if not quite endless, perhaps) yet to be explored.

Thus, it now seems to me that this particular forum (Game Guides) is invaluable for new builders, at least, and needs some proper care and attention. We'd end up with more informed build requests and better finalized builds (and yes, I include myself in this) with a higher level of guidance from here. Otherwise we run the risk of simply churning out the same stuff again and again to those wishing to increase their knowledge. And all things should be interrogated, and those questions encouraged, obviously, lest arrogance creep in.

However, bringing this section of the Guild up to speed will take much time and effort (and I'm really not wishing to demean anything that's here already, it's been brilliant for me, despite apparent evidence to the contrary), and we can't demand that of members.

So, how about we do as Tyr Templar did back in the day for the Yardstick Builds thread, and ask for a raising of hands for who might provide what's missing? We're adults (most of the time) and know our own strengths in build terms, so, over to you...

And no, this isn't just a simple way for me to get out of doing anything, before you start! Please tell me if I'm talking nonsense again.

Cheers

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
I can't promise when, but I believe I could take the fighter's guide under my wings.

Teaching all these dirty tricks that will allow even pure blockheads, without umd, to succeed in the harshest of modules.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Thanks Valerfor! (Where's that old dancing banana emoji gone?)

I'll tell you what, to show I'm not running away: why don't I try a CoT one? (I'm so going to hate myself in the morning.) I've used it a lot, and in different ways, so maybe...You will all, of course, have editorial rights on my draft.

Cheers

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content: I believe I can do a sorcerer guide. The core of it must be building, battle tactics and spell selection. But there is more to playing a caster, so this can be fun!

For my own part - now both Deekin and Boo have stopped rolling on their backs in mirth (they seem to have bonded over this) - I trust I'll be able to consult with the great and good about mixing CoT with Cleric in particular, should it prove necessary (more hilarity from kobold and hamster - stern looks from Stag seem to have no effect).

We're on our way!

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
https://neverwintervault.org/project/nw ... ave-forums

I'm downloading MS SQL Server 2017 Express Edition right now and gonna have a playaround to see what I can do

Edit: MS SQL is just way too hard for me to use. I'll find some other alternative to read the database when I get time. Some comments suggest the database misses quite a few posts - hope its not true.
Update: Found a way to load the file through some freeware software (see screenshot), but can't read the content of the posts. bit of a hassle. Gonna go back to MS SQL. Got a youtube video to help now.



Update 2: I'm stuck. I'm going to give up for now I think. Probably beyond my skill level. That being said, if anyone knows how to use this software they are welcome to post some advice. I'll leave screenshots from my last attempt here. I'm using MS SQL Management Studio 18, from the Microsoft website.

posts.author: DoesntPlayAnymore
posts.content: Hey, Orion, what is it you are trying to do? Recreate the forums locally from the SQL DB? Maybe I can help.

posts.author: Orion
posts.content: I'm honestly just trying to read the database that Baelos created from his save the forum project (https://neverwintervault.org/project/nw ... ave-forums) which was saved in SQL DB format. I'm looking for character guides that would otherwise be lost to add to the resource list for builders and new/intermediate/advanced players. Wayback Archive is missing a few pages and was wondering if this SQL database would have these missing pages. I think Baelos tried to recreate the forums but they dont seem complete. There seems to be quite a bit of good stuff in here. Anyway what do you think? Is there any more user friendly software to view MDF database files?

posts.author: DoesntPlayAnymore

posts.author: DoesntPlayAnymore
posts.content:
@Orion2019 Just want to give you an update on the forum archive. I'm on vacation and have been working on the data base like it's my job. Mostly by trial and error. A seasoned Web developer would probably be done in a few hours but I'm very much not that.

I found an OK data structure for the thing, generated some nice looking HTML files with internal linking, the bare minimum but still pretty and very reliable. That thing was NINE GIGABYTES. Just for Nwn1! So simple doesn't work.

What works is having the data indexed and organised in a well thought out way and fetch it with Javascript into one HTML document procedually, basically like a Web app. In this way, the entire dataset for both games is only about 250 mb total - completely manageable.

So I've been learning Javascript. Turns out "fetching" hundreds of thousands data items directly from the hard disc without running a server with is not something Javascript wants you to do. The alternative is having one huge data structure that gets loaded immediately but then you have a slow sluggish app on startup (I tried.) I think the ideal solution is somewhere in between and I've found a (hacky) workaround to the loading problem that conceptually should work when scaled. Now I just need to reorganise and index the data (for at least the 10th time) to follow the model and code the thing.

It's been a ton of fun and I have learnt so much, so thank you for posting a great dataset with an interesting challenge!

Sendt fra min WAS-LX1 med Tapatalk

the "s" in organize
I'm not a native english speaker and I spent many minutes pondering the correct way of spelling that word, too stubborn to look it up. Or maybe yes, that was a double bluff. Anyway, were Kail and Hip part of creating the CBC? I think Hip did the local build search archive, right?

posts.author: gkorjax
posts.content: The brits pretty much only have 25 letters in the alphabet. Almost every word that has a strong Z sound,they spell with an S.  I think the only time they use a z is to spell zed.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
I get you completely there, gkorjax. I remember getting into deep trouble with a big boss at work one time while I was an editor for amending his words in an article to read "organize" and "civilization" with zeds (and they are indeed zeds, not zees). I wheeled out the Oxford English Dictionary and he had to concede I was correct. The problem was/is that it's a kick against the perceived Americaniz(s)ation of English by the English (the Welsh just sat in a corner giggling and throwing more double ells and dees into everything, while the Scots and Irish had other things to worry about). As a general rule of thumb, I will use a zed if the word is pronounced with an "eyes", and an ess if it's pronounced  with an "ice". Thus organize, civilize and realize.

Ain't language grand?!

From comparing just the number of items to the largest id (they are made sequentially) I can tell you there is missing:

  • 50+ posts from nwn1 ( 82836 / 82886 )
  • 0 topics from nwn2 ( 7522 / 7522 )
  • 0 posts from nwn2 ( 65545 / 65545 )
The topics missing from nwn1 are id's: [3301, 3303, 3305, 3306, 3315, 3317, 3320, 3322]
The missing posts are:
Spoiler[22803,  22813,  22819,  22838,  22847,  22852,  22861,  22866,  22869,  22871,  22873,  22876,  22884,  22886,  22890,  22979,  22981,  22983,  22986,  22988,  23002,  23006,  23008,  23010,  23012,

Checking the thing with automated get requests at 1 second each (very optimistic considering probably wont be able to enter id's directly, have to do some weird comparison algorithm with google site search, and there being a max for how many http get requests you can do per hour before the server blocks for a certain amount of time) 9948 / 60 / 60 = 2.763 hours, ~ 2:45 in human. That's under best, improbable circumstances. I don't think it's worth it, and entering that stuff by hand is by god not worth it.

I think this source is depleted, detective. @Orion2019
